comment: Would give it three stars because they serve it everywhere in Italy, but taste wise it does not deserve the ranking
Way too soft and light. No kick. Chemical aftertaste
Not bad. Not cragganmore but it is ok
Apples and pear on the nose, intensely fruity.  Butter crème, and bourbon-y sweetness on the palate.  Light cocoa and almonds that turns to fruit on the finish.
A very smooth and soft whisky, I'd recommend inexperienced whisk(e)y drinkers this one. Hints of vanilla, yet subtlety spicy. Goes down smooth.
I know whisky is distilled beer but Glen Grant 10 really tastes like it. Sometimes that's what you're in the mood for but most of the time it's not quite complex enough for me.
Spicy full bodies and complex dram for its age. Great value for money.  Nose of salted caramel and banana. Young scotch done well.
Actually a decent malt at this price point but requires time to warm up to it! My pick for sub $50 AUD!
Booooring... But cheap so decent gateway whisky
Nice to drink whiskey.  A bit fruity and light. Would recommend any time as ita a good value for thw price.
Fresh grass, toffee, light honey , spring breeze , toasted barley and pear. Medium to full bodied. Lingering on and on. Yes its definitely best single malt scotch 10 years.
Gentle and soft, but too soft. It is fruity on the nose, banana and pear. Too soft and simple in the mouth. But there is always one day that you re just in the mood to have a gentle dram
Very good dram. Very good value for the money

Nose- floral vanillas, honey, 
Tasting- toasted cereal, rich but light, great dram for the price
Fairly smooth with gentle heather honey sweetness and spice. Soft smoke. Pretty well balanced. Certainly good but nothing to get excited about. Not available in Ontario.
Very light, sweet mildly fruity and easy to drink. Not a complex whisky by any means, but if it's all ya got not too bad

Maybe the kind of classic Scotch that doesn’t make any new fans. What they miss is a nose of ripe apples and light beer, a honey palate close to mead, followed by a mildly spicy finish that lingers.
23-23-22-22=90
great on the nose - though perhaps i've never nosed toasted grain

Apples, vanilla and malted cereal on the nose. Roasted almonds and slight citrus note on the palate. Finish is relatively short, with aftertaste of fresh oak spice. Not impressive, but not bad either.

Really kind of a lightweight for me, and not in a good way. The nose is fresh fruit salad (apple and melon especially), with a squeeze of lemon, a little pear, and some mild vanilla. The palate is gentle and backloaded with vanilla, with those apple and pear notes in the midpalate. I'm not heartbroken that this one's being phased out for the significantly better 12 year old!

Another stop in our SDT tour, a quest between 5 of us to,sample an offering from every active Scottish distillery.  Now in round 6, and this one offered by @Generously_Paul .  I couldn’t finish this one...sorry guys.  Just too much of a plastic-y aroma...simply couldn’t get past it.  Did manage to take a sip, and just as I thought...overly sweet with that manufactured corn syrup flavor.  This needs more time in the barrel...much more time,   Thanks for the pour @Generously_Paul —-acknowledge and move on
Sweet and little rough. Notes of honey and vanilla, some camomile and citrus zest
Actually 5 year (not in this app). Not too bad, a cheap drink. A bit of burn, grainy, slightly smoky.

Fresh grain aromas. Flavour much the same, quite simple & easy with a licorice finish.
Slightly sweet/ vanilla, hint of peat/smoke?
Light amber color. Fruity scents. Fruity, smooth, finish.

Older, independently bottled Glen Grants can be of exceptional quality after having slept in oak barrels for a few decades. This 10-year-old expression, however, is a very simple and undemanding Speyside Single Malt. The aroma is understated, sweet and fruity with hints of pears, nuts and fresh hay. Spicy, young and spirity in the arrival, there are notes of lemon juice, red currants and honey before dry refill cask bitterness takes over. Wood tannins and faint vanilla characterize the rather short finish. A cheap beginners whisky without any complexity.

RATING: 3.0/5.0 stars ≙ 79 pts → AVERAGE

The nose is weak, but there are wafts of apples/pears with a touch of honey. The apples are more prominent on the palate, with a pleasant spice so that is all reminiscent of apple pie. The finish is slightly bitter and short, but I suppose it's forgivable. Not bad.

Rapport qualité prix intéressant 
Whiskey simple

Nose: Vanilla, honeysuckle, pear, orange, almond, hazelnut, malt.

Palate: Sweet malty arrival. A slight herbal note almost like an ale as it develops. Vanilla and fruit. Definite nutty flavours - cashews, hazelnuts. Reasonable texture.

Finish: Medium. Sweet malt and spicy toffee notes.

I'd argue that this is one of the better affordable drams. At the price it is good value, however for a few dollars more you can get the 12 year old, which is better all round.  Likewise, for a few dollars less you can get the Major’s Reserve, which is priced to compete with middle-shelf blended scotch and, although hardly a complex malt, is excellent value.

A very easy, straightforward dram and a great choice for a complete beginner who wants something very friendly and unchallenging. Similar in some respects to Glen Moray Elgin Classic, but that is sweetly fruity whereas this is solidly about warm, sweet malt.

“Above Average" : 3 stars

I just opened this one to replace the now gone Aberfeldy 12 as the light and cheap whisky from my rotation.

The nose is lovely with ripe pear, floral sweetness and a hint of lemon citrus in the background.

The taste is sweet and reminds me of caramel and honeysuckle. There is no alcohol burn at all.

The finish is also sweet and carry a little bit of spiceness and a tad more bitterness than I would like, but nothing that would ruin it.

Although I don’t agree with it, I don’t think that Jim Murray was completely out of his mind when he called this one Single Malt Scotch of the year 2017 (10 yrs & under). 

This is a lovely whisky with an unbelievable low price tag and certainly is a must buy for fans of floral/sweet speysiders.
It's not disgusting, but I can't drink it neat. Cola friendly.
It’s sweet and bit smoky at the end. Pretty nice for lady.
Slight honey notes from bourbon barrels, smoky. Fairly standard scotch.
slight smokey, also in a cocktail-loved it

You can tell it's going to be young from the first sniff. Faint pears, vanilla, straw, hay, cinnamon and sugarcane. Thin mouthfeel, but 40% ABV, so not surprising. The palate is a little better, with white grapes, pears, and your other typical vanilla, woody notes flavors etc. Decent 10 year, but a short and dry white pepper finish to me. It needs some smoke, peat, or sherry... something else. 2.75 for me. Thanks for the taste though @Generously_Paul. The theme of this dram needs to be a bit of a boring song. I am thinking "Tom Dooley" by the Kingston Trio. LOL.
One of the best affordable whiskies on the market. If you want an intro to jot just Speyside, but whisky in general, this is perfect! Sweet, spicy and smooth. It’s a great piece of nectar.

NOSE: Lager beer with honey and vanilla. Some fresh pear. Hint of petrol.

PALATE: Light oily texture with some pear juice and honey. Very low in spice, not much bite. Finish with some barrel char and bitter cacao.

OVERALL: Really friendly and easy sipper. Great for beer or bourbon fans.
Light color, light body & light floral taste. Worthy of being an everyday dram but only when purchased for a fair price.
Sweet and fruity. Beautiful 10 yr old malt.
Very fresh light and pleasant Fruit and floral notes

Another sample from our Scotch Distillery samples tour.  Glen Grant, not a rarity, but nothing I have experienced yet, until tonight. 

There are faint aromas, almost diluted.  Oak, white pepper, apples and hay.  Some earthiness, like a dry and dusty backroad.  A grapiness gradually works it way through over time along with some banana and honey sweetness. 

The palate is light, diluted and sweet.  Just four adjectives: Honey, vanilla, oak, ginger. 

The finish is short, woody and dry. 

This is a rather drab expression.  Diluted was the underlying current from nose to finish.  No zing, flash, pizazz or flavor.  It could, however, be a satisfactory summer sipper.  Thanks @Generously_Paul for the sample. [83/100][Tasted: 6/22/18]
Light and floral. Full mouth feeling.

It’s time for another distillery tour sample as we work our way towards the finish line later this summer.  This pour was given to me by my friend @Generously_Paul.  Glen Grant 10.  This offering from another Speyside distillery clocks in at the minimum 40% ABV and is a beautiful yellow gold in the tasting glass.  It looks pretty oily, but reveals big droplets around the rim of the glass with some very thick legs.  Obviously, there’s lots of water in this one.

The nose was extremely weak- even given some significant time to develop.  Weak oak notes and a hint of sweetness that faded after 10 minutes.  There was nothing else discernible no matter how long I kept my nose in it.  Very boring.

The palate and finish didn’t really amount to much, either.  Some weird corn notes and more faint oak.  The finish was short and dry and really was gone in a flash.  This thing needs some serious ABV punch, I don’t know why it was watered down to 40%.  

Overall, this one is very uninspiring and weak.  I’ve heard good things about the older bottles, but this offering doesn’t inspire me to put down the money to find out.  2.25-2.5 stars.  Keep moving, nothing to see here.  Cheers.

Stop number 92 on the SDT is Glen Grant. Originally founded by the Grant brothers John and James in 1840, this Speyside distillery has gone through a few different owners including Chivas Brothers. In 2005 it was sold to the Italian company Campari Group and is now the best selling single malt scotch in Italy. Glen Grant has a respectable output of 5.9 million liters per year. This 10 year old single malt is their youngest of their core range that includes a 12 and 18. I don’t know if they have any NAS releases. Bottled at 40% ABV and is chill filtered and has colorant added making it a pale straw. 

The nose starts with hay and dry grasses and some fruitiness in the form of apples and green grapes. There is a balanced, bourbony oak and a nuttiness in the form of walnuts, pecans and cashews. Minty, salty, earthy and a bit gravely/dusty. Malty/barley sugar with some honey and ginger. Light coconut and honeydew. A bit of banana and a lemony-orange citrus. Light vanilla and floral notes like potpourri. There are plenty of notes to pick up on here, but they are all weak. It’s clear that refill casks were used.

Very little going on with the palate. Malty, honey, tea and some vanilla. A little peppery spice and some cinnamon. Oak, ginger, citrus and almonds. 

A light bodied mouthfeel that is thin but mouthwatering. 
A short finish with tea, oak, ginger and almonds.  

Nothing much going on with this one. The nose has some decent complexity, but it, along with the palate, falls flat and is quite uninspired. Even at the $40 price point that I paid, there are far better options out there. I wish I had ponied up the extra $10 and gone with the 12 year old. Oh well, another one off the list. 2.5-2.75 rounded up to a 3
Cheers
Quite intense floral, fruity &  vanilla nose. Palate is fruity and malty, but less intense. 2 stars and 1/2.

nose is very simple, it's sweet and fruity. green apple, pear drops, cereal and honeysuckle.

palate is very much the same, leads with cerealy flavours, but the honey and sweet fruit quickly appears before the whole sensation seems to vanish and leaves you needing another sip. 

very simple and for price is well balanced although not very  complex at all. hot weather whisky this one when something light sweet and refreshing is required.

Very delicate soft taste and spiceness
Light spayside.  Good spice. Drinkable and  a good “go to”.
Fresh pear and vanilla nose, toffee on the tongue, nutty finish. Easy and smooth.

Quite nice inexpensive single malt. Easy approach to speayside whisky.
Nose. Green pear and tobacco. A hint of vanilla.
Mouth. Lots of the grain and beer that comes from.

Best cheap single malt.
Fantastically sweet vanilla taste and a smooth mouthfeel.  With a nice bite at the end that reminds you what you're drinking.
Pear on nose. Very winey for me. Citrus, sweet, light. Bittery, long aftertaste.

Honey oat aroma 
Strong malt hit at the front no real heat with some pear and some sherry cask  notes

Honey-lemon tea on the nose.  The body is possibly the lightest scotch I've ever had.  The palate starts off with cereal grains forward, then with honey sweetness as a finish, mingling with oak spice. The honey character does take a second or third sip to discern, but there's nothing here that's offensive.  As a component of the Chivas Regal blend, I gather this is used to smooth it out.  Still, very drinkable but making very little ripple in the pond.



My Rating Glossary:  

Two Stars:           "I'd rather be drinking lite beer."
Two 1/2 Stars:    "Posh rubbish."
Three Stars:        "I love whisk(e)y.  This is average love."
Three 1/2 Stars: "May buy again."
Four Stars:          "I've got to get you into my life."
Four 1/2 Stars:   "Better than drugs."
Five Stars:           "Life is good.  Whisky makes it better."
